title: Cryogenic Characterization of HfO2 Memristors
text:
Associated with Tickle College of Engineering at the University of Tennessee
June 2025 - July 2025
This page details my work as an Undergraduate Researcher under Dr. Garrett Rose, focusing on low-temperature memory design for quantum and neuromorphic computing applications. The project involved two main components: experimental evaluation of memristor failure at cryogenic temperatures and the design of a custom PCB (“Octopus PCB”).

title: Cryogenic Characterization of HfO2 Memristors
section: RESET-Failure Evaluation of HfO₂-Based Memristors at Cryogenic Temperatures
text:
RESET-Failure Evaluation of HfO₂-Based Memristors at Cryogenic Temperatures
Skills: Python (Programming Language) · C++ · Keysight B1500A Semiconductor Tester · Data Analysis
Author: Kanoa Parker
Mentors: Rocco Febbo, Dr. Garrett Rose

Memristors are two-terminal memory devices with programmable resistance, first theorized by Leon Chua in 1971 and fabricated by Hewlett-Packard in 2008. Recent advancements in manufacturing have made memristors more accessible. With the integration of CMOS, there are hopes of developing an in-memory computation system, particularly for environments requiring cryogenic operation, such as space or quantum computing systems.
This study investigates RESET failure in HfO₂-based memristors at cryogenic temperatures. RESET failure is defined as a destructive event in which the device becomes permanently stuck at a fixed resistance.
Using a B1500A Semiconductor Device Analyzer and a FormFactor PMC200 cryogenic probe station, the applied RESET voltage was progressively lowered at 70 K until failure occurred. This data was used to refine an existing Verilog-A model, updating it to account for cryogenic behavior. The enhanced model supports the design of more robust memory systems for low-temperature applications. Results predict a decrease in memristor resistance and an increase in power consumption at cryogenic temperatures.
Download Technical Report (PDF)

Project Poster

title: Cryogenic Characterization of HfO2 Memristors
text:
Octopus PCB
Skills: Printed Circuit Board (PCB) Design · 3D Design · PCB Design
Author: Kanoa Parker
Mentors: Rocco Febbo, Dr. Garrett Rose
The main function of the PCB is to allow the user to connect two 25 Position D-Sub Male Cable to then be connected to Analog Input Pixie 6365 or a Analog Output Pixie 6738.






Final PCB on Mounting Board







Outline of PCB











3D Rendering of PCB





Download Schematic (PDF)
The input from the 25 D-Sub cable goes through a 100 ohm resistor which can be bypassed with a switch. It then enters into the analog input cable. There is a second switch which then connects it to the analog output cable. The analog output can be run with the pin still connected to the analog input at the same time. The analog input can not be run while connected to the analog output. In addition each of the pins can be accessed through a RF Connector or through test pads located before the analog output side.

title: Research & Projects
text: This page showcases my hands-on research and engineering project experience, highlighting my ability to apply theoretical knowledge to practical challenges.

title: Research & Projects
text:
Academic Research

Cryogenic Characterization of HfO₂ Memristors
Undergraduate Researcher | University of Tennessee Knoxville (Summer 2025)


RESET-Failure Evaluation: Investigated failure mechanisms in HfO₂-based memristors at 77K using a cryogenic probe station and semiconductor analyzer.
Octopus PCB: Designed a custom PCB for connecting D-Sub cables to Analog Input/Output Pixies, enabling flexible testing configurations.



A Tribological Study of The Optimization of Pizza Making
STLE Atlanta Student Poster Session (June 2025)


Investigated the optimum ratio of flour to dough to minimize friction and prevent burning during pizza making.
Presented findings at the Annual 2025 STLE Meeting.



SLA Additive Manufacturing: A Review of Resin Formulations and Patterning’s Impact on Abrasiveness
STLE Atlanta Student Poster Session (June 2025)


Investigated the impact of surface modifications and resin formulations on the wear resistance of SLA-printed components.
Presented findings at the 2025 Annual STLE Meeting.

title: Research & Projects
text:
Clinic Projects

Regenerative Load for HITL Test System (Work in Progress - Fall 2025)
Client: Exolambda
Students: …, Kanoa Parker, …
Advisor: …
Project Liasons: …
My Contributions:

Collaborating with a team to design and build a regenerative load for a Hardware-in-the-Loop (HITL) test system, requiring a minimum of three variable loads at 48 V and 10 A capacity.
Heavily involved in the physical building and testing of regenerative aspects, utilizing buck and boost converters and grid-tie inverters to refine the overall architecture.
Coordinated with team members on variable load development, ensuring interface compatibility (connectors, test points).
Developed two distinct architecture setups: one feeding power back to AC mains via a grid-tie inverter, and another generating DC voltage back to the PSU.
Expanded systems-level design capabilities in an open-ended project environment.



Redesign of Low-Cost Sensors used in Community-engaged Air Pollution Monitoring (Fall 2024)
Client: UC Berkeley - Civil & Environmental Engineering
Students: Zhian Zhou, Carmen Horenstein, Madeleine Kan, Thomas Lilygren, Matthew Molinar, Julia Manese, Megan Kho, Kanoa Parker, Marcos Ng Carrion
Advisor: Dr. Yifan Wu
Project Liaisons: Dr. Chelsea Preble, Dr. Tom Kirchstetter
Download Project Poster (PDF)
My Contributions:

Updated communication hardware for an existing air sensor system used to measure air quality around industrial areas of Oakland.
Researched and identified suitable wireless communication protocols and hardware options to transmit sensor data to a web server.
Considered numerous outside factors, including location constraints, community WiFi access, signal strength in industrial areas, and LoRaWAN gateway availability.
Navigated significant system limitations imposed by battery efficiency, which constrained sampling and data transmission rates, impacting overall system operational life.
Developed a “large system thinking” mindset, identifying factors beyond traditional electrical engineering to create a functional product for public good.

title: Research & Projects
text:
Coursework & Personal Projects

Digital Audio Effects Guitar Pedals (Work in Progress)
Final Project: Electronic and Microprocessor Systems (ENGR155, Fall 2025)

Developing guitar pedals to add audio effects (degradation chorus, reverb) using an external ADC, FPGA, and STM32 MCU in tandem.


Electronic and Microprocessor Systems (ENGR155) Lab Assignments
Lab Assignments
Note: These assignments required students to utilize LLMs and critically reflect on their performance and utility.



Analog Operational Amplifier Design
Final Project: Analog Circuit Design (ENGR151, Spring 2025)
(Collaborator: Slader Spoor)

Designed and constructed a fully operational amplifier from discrete 2N3904 and 2N3906 BJTs, utilizing a suite of passive components (resistors, diodes, capacitors).
Integrated key subcircuits including a current mirror for biasing, an emitter follower for buffering, a Class AB output stage for high-fidelity signal delivery, and a common emitter with degeneration for stable gain.
Achieved critical design objectives: high-impedance differential inputs, low output impedance, and high DC gain, demonstrating proficiency in fundamental analog circuit design principles.



Electrocardiogram
Final Project: Electronic and Magnetic Circuits and Devices (ENGR084, Fall 2024)
(Collaborator: Caiya Coggshall)

Designed and built an electrocardiogram to measure the electrical activity of the heart.
Used an instrumentation amplifier, high pass filter, low pass filter, and notch filter to process the signal and visualized it on an oscilloscope.
Skills: Analog Circuit Design, Oscilloscope, Circuit Design.



Autonomous Underwater Vehicle
Final Project: Experimental Engineering (ENGR080, Spring 2024)

Developed an underwater robot in a team of 4 students to test various nose designs underwater.
Utilized modified pressure sensors as pitot tubes to measure relative velocity.
Employed anemometers to measure wind speed and force sensors to measure drag force.
Skills: Integrated Circuit Design, MATLAB, Soldering, Arduino.



Automatic Ball Feeder
Final Project: Introduction to Engineering Design (ENGR004, Fall 2024)

In a group of 5 students, constructed a device that would feed baseballs periodically into a Hack Attack Jr. pitching machine.
Designed a funnel and rail system to store the balls before they were dispensed into the machine.
Implemented a motor controller and a wheel to vary the speed at which balls were released.
Skills: Woodworking, Integrated Circuit Design, Teamwork, Communication, AutoCAD.



Remotely Operated Vehicle
Final Project: Introduction to Engineering Systems (ENGR079, Fall 2023)

Designed a robot capable of vertical movement in water in collaboration with another student.
Integrated pressure sensors for depth measurement and thermistors for water temperature monitoring.
Utilized PWM control and motors to adjust the depth of the robot.
Skills: Integrated Circuit Design, Soldering, LabVIEW, Communication.

title: A Tribological Study of The Optimization of Pizza Making
text:
Presented at the Annual 2025 STLE Meeting
June 2025
Authors: Dr. Gordon Krauss, Miranda Brandt, Leilani Elkaslasy, Kanoa Parker

Pizza makers have consistently faced a challenge when dusting pizza dough with flour. Too much flour and the pizza burns in the oven, not enough and the dough does not slide off the peel. To find the answer to this dilemma varying amounts of flour were added to pizza dough and the effect on the dough’s ability to slide on a surface effectively was examined. Through this, an optimum ratio of semolina flour to pizza dough was determined in order to give pizza makers everywhere a reliable measurement of flour they could use to overcome friction without inducing burning.
Download Student Poster (PDF)

title: Kanoa Parker
text:
I am a senior in Electrical Engineering at Harvey Mudd College, motivated by the principle of using thoughtful, informed systems design to address pressing systemic challenges. My core focus is the escalating energy demands of modern computation. Dedicated to creating scalable and sustainable solutions, my research centers on Power Electronics and Integrated Circuit (IC) Design, specifically developing efficient, reliable hardware architectures for AI and data centers.
My background spans the hardware stack: from analyzing device physics (characterizing memristors at 77K) to building system-level power stages (designing regenerative loads for HITL testing).
I am actively pursuing PhD opportunities to create scalable, high-reliability hardware solutions that bridge the gap between novel devices and practical energy systems, ultimately contributing to closing the energy gap without sacrificing environmental or societal well-being.




Integrated Circuit Power Efficiency & Microelectronics: Novel device architectures, HfO₂-based resistive memory, and low-temperature memory design for applications in quantum and neuromorphic computing.
Cryogenic Device Testing & Semiconductor Analysis: Expertise in high-level instrument control (Keysight B1500A Semiconductor Device Analyzer, PyVISA, custom Python bindings). Characterized HfO₂ memristors at 77 K; data used to refine existing Verilog-A models for cryogenic architecture design.
Embedded Control & Analog Circuit Design: Hands-on experience designing and physically constructing complex analog subcircuits (e.g., operational amplifier from scratch using BJTs, including current mirrors and Class AB output stage). Demonstrated proficiency in digital control (STM32 microcontroller programming, generating PWM, interpreting motor encoder interrupts, integrating sensors and ESP8266 webservers).
System-Level Design & Systems Thinking: Proven ability to solve open-ended engineering challenges and coordinate complex system interfaces. Experience includes building regenerative loads utilizing power electronics (buck/boost converters, AC grid tie inverters) for Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) test systems, and adapting designs based on critical real-world constraints such as limited battery life and environmental factors (e.g., winter reducing efficiency, summer heat damaging components).

title: SLA Additive Manufacturing: A Review of Resin Formulations and Patterning’s Impact on Abrasiveness
text:
Authors: Dr. Gordon Krauss, Miranda Brandt, Leilani Elkaslasy, Kanoa Parker
Date: May 2025

This project explores how surface modifications—such as patterning and top-layer doping with ceramic or metal additives—impact the wear resistance, abrasiveness, and sliding friction of components fabricated via stereolithography (SLA)-based additive manufacturing. Disks were printed using a DLP resin printer with commercial ceramic and denture resin materials. Various surface patterns and additive compositions were tested.
Wear tests were performed using the Pin-on-Disk method with a Universal Micro-Tribometer (UMT-2) against 52100 steel balls. The study compared the performance of alumina disks with and without a porcelain coating, evaluated the effects of incorporating porcelain powder into denture resin, and assessed patterned versus unpatterned surfaces.
Findings were presented at the 2025 Annual STLE Meeting in Atlanta Georgia. The talk focused on the effects on wear resistance and friction that porcelain coatings had on alumina disks.
Download Student Poster (PDF)

My core focus is the escalating energy demands of modern computation. Dedicated to creating scalable and sustainable solutions, my research centers on Power Electronics and Integrated Circuit (IC) Design, specifically developing efficient, reliable hardware architectures for AI and data centers
I am a final-year Electrical Engineering undergraduate at Harvey Mudd College, dedicated to addressing the energy crisis in modern computing. My research focuses on Power Electronics and Integrated Circuit (IC) Design, with a specific interest in developing efficient architectures for AI and data centers.
My background spans the hardware stack: from analyzing device physics (characterizing memristors at 77K) to building system-level power stages (designing regenerative loads for HITL testing). I am actively pursuing PhD opportunities to create scalable, high-reliability hardware solutions that bridge the gap between novel devices and practical energy systems.


Research Interests

Integrated Circuit Power Efficiency: Novel device architectures, resistive memory, low-temperature memory design.
Signal Processing & Control Systems: Embedded control, digital signal processing, system integration for real-world applications.
Microelectronics: Memristors, cryogenic testing, semiconductor device analysis.
System-Level Design: Hardware-in-the-Loop (HITL) systems, power electronics (buck/boost converters, grid tie inverters).
